Vessels that carry oxygenated blood are colored red and vessels that carry deoxygenated blood are colored blue on diagrams and models. Just because a vessel is red in color, does not mean it is an artery. For example, the pulmonary arteries are illustrated as blue on diagrams and models because they carry deoxygenated blood, not because it is a vein.

This Video was amazing, firstly this guy is funny, and his first memorable quote is “in truth, he heart is really just a pump- a big, wet, muscly brute of a pump.” His exasperation comes from the fact the heart is not really all about “love”, it is just there to keep you going. He says the heart is really only concerned with maintaining pressure. The video goes on to say that the heart is a very unique organ, and generates “high hydrostatic pressure to pump blood out to the heart, while also creating low pressure to bring it back in” meaning it has to keep high and low pressure all in one organ. To think this is just the introduction on the heart!
The next part starts off with facts, like the size and shape of the heart, and that the heart grows with you. Next we learn about the pericardium which is made up of apparently two layers, the first is the fibrous pericardium. This layer is made up of really dense connective tissue which helps keep the heart in since heart beats are pretty intense and without this the organ would flail about wildly in the chest. The inner pericardium has fluid, a natural lubricant to keep the heart moving well. He also goes over the layers of the heart as well as the chambers of the heart and valves. Fun fact: the “lub dub” sound is actually the opening and closing of the valves in the heart. Cool right? I think the thing here that he doesn’t exactly say but solves my question of why is the pulmonary artery called “artery” if the blood is deoxygenated? This video breaks it down like this: veins bring blood to the heart, arteries push it away from the heart. Which in MOST cases means oxygenated blood in arteries, and deoxygenated in veins. But not in the immediate heart area!
This video is very through while being very interesting and funny. I even had an “ah-ha” moment. It goes over everything from the misconception of the heart being an organ to ‘love’, to general facts about the heart and circulatory system, and includes blood pressure and interesting information about the lungs. All in all this would be a great little video to show in class, or watch in your own time to maybe clarify any questions.
BONUS: It also has a second part to it which talks about McDreamy from Grey’s and everyone knows how much I love that show, and that video is also great. The video also has some awesome information about how cardiac tissues vary from regular tissues, and the intrinsic cardiac system.

What's the Point?

My heart, your heart...
they all look alike,
two puffy mounds at the top,
tapering down into a spike.

But just why is it
that they all look the same?
Shouldn't a person's heart be
as individual as his name?

Well, if you look a bit closer
you will readily see
that everyone's heart is
just as different as he (or she!).

For it's not the shape, 
nor even the size,
But what's inside
that is truly the prize.

The mound on the right...
holds memories so dear
only the good ones
from year after year.

And the mound on the left,
is filled to the brim
with the light of sweet passion,
that never grows dim.

Now the part in the middle,
is where deep love resides.
Its strength can be fierce,
Yet here, too, fragility hides.

Then finally, slowly,
the heart slopes to a fine edge..
coming to a sharp point
in the shape of a wedge.

This point is for balance
between all the parts
which is very important
for those with full hearts!

And if you look more closely
you will see right at the tip
a tiny little hole
no bigger than a pin.

This is the place 
where all our sorrows go
They stay with us a short while,
then seep out with the flow.

Hearts can be lonely,
Hearts can be sad...
Hearts can be faithful,
In good times and bad

But no matter the shape,
Nor how big or how small,
Your heart is a gift,
To be shared with all.

5:42 that's not entirely true, atrium contracting only gives 20% of blood, the rest goes in the ventricle because ventricular pressure after systole is lower than the atrial pressure. If you're interested to know more about this, search Wiggers diagram on youtube, and also it's useful to know terms such as preload (end diastolic volume) and afterload (arterial pressure that the force of ventricles contracting needs to overcome). Also, kidneys are the organ which regulates long term blood pressure via renin-angiotensin(-aldosteron).

Thought bubble:
Our muscles do not technically need oxygen to live, it is actually our body's need to remove carbon dioxide. Without the ability to remove CO2, our bodies would build up carbonic acid (H2CO3) which is too unstable and breaks apart into bicarbonate and a hydrogen ion (HCO3- + H+). Hydrogen ions directly influences our bodies ph level, and too much of it would make our blood very acidic.
So we need to breath to rid ourselves of CO2.

Fun with chemistry. :)

I realize that the presentation is "simplified", but you still don't have the physiology quite correct.  The right ventricle isn't responsible for a negative gradient to suck blood back to the right side.  Ventricular filling is actually an active process, the result of active ventricular relaxation and only partially the result of atrial contraction.  It is not known that the first heart sound is actually the result of coaptation of valve leaflets per se. (Oh, and it's squamous with a long "a".) The diastolic pressure is a reflection of the elasticity of the resistance vessels in the arterial tree. Adequate resistance is also required to maintain systolic BP.  The heart actually does several things: Yes, it must maintain perfusion pressure, but it must also circulate an adequate volume of blood (to which you alluded) and it must maintain pulsatile flow, which for some reason, the body's other organs seem to like, and on which some neural pathways depend.
